title: Cursive
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019151627/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Terminology](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019151627/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Terminology) : Cursive**

Being Cursive is a property of [typography](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019151627/http:/typophile.com/wiki/typography) and [Calligraphy](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019151627/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Calligraphy) which implies a certain inclination or angular tilt, either positive or negative, relative to the orthogonal "y" axis.

In type, both [Oblique](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019151627/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Oblique) and [Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019151627/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Italic) are Cursive in the sense that they imply some sort of inclination, somehow reminiscent of written language. Other examples of Cursive may include some [Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019151627/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Script) types.
author: gabssnake
